indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Designed model for multi-agency cooperation in high risk cases of domestic violence 2. Joint protocol for dealing with DV cases developed

baseline.comment: 1. Inefficient multi-agency cooperation in high risk DV cases at local level. 2. Existing protocol for dealing with DV victims from 2012 needs alignment with the legal provisions of the new Law on Prevention, Combatting and Protection from Domestic Violence

target.comment: 1. Establish model for multi-agency response in protecting high-risk cases of domestic violence in at least 3 municipalities in the country 2. Develop a joint protocol for coordinated and multi-sector response to high-risk domestic violence cases

actual.comment:
1. UNDP in coordination with UN Women supported the governmental inter-ministerial working group to develop relevant bylaws that would support efficient implementation of the legal provisions envisaged with the Law on prevention and protection of domestic violence in 2014.
2. The Joint protocol establishes the legal background for the development of the multi-agency cooperation in high-risk domestic violence cases on a local level. This referral mechanism has been tested in three selected municipalities (Kavadarci, Kumanovo and Stip) to avoid duplication of procedures among institutions and to ensure prevention from re-victimization.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1. Number of start-ups supported % of women employed % of young people (aged up to 29) employed % of Roma employed % of start-ups established by people with disabilities
2. Number of participants who completed the training on business plans development
3. Number of additional jobs created in successful small companies % of young staff (aged up to 29) employed % women employed % of supported initiatives that will enable the development of innovative solutions
4. Number of active Youth Info Clubs;
5. Number of downloads of PRV.mk mobile application and number of PRV.MK website visitors
6. Number of individuals at risk of social exclusion who received support through the Community Works Programme % of young people (aged up to 29) who received support through the Community Works Programme % of increase in the number of end beneficiaries (recipients of social services) of the Community Works Programme
7. Number of participants who attended the training on providing professional services to the elderly and obtained a certificate/ license, as part of the Community Works Programme
8. Number of companies supported with a concrete plan for enhanced marketing and presentation of products and services
9. Number of tools developed and provided for local partners to improve monitoring and real time reporting on Employment Programmes' results
10. Number of sector-specific and/or local/regional skills needs assessment studies conducted and curriculum design supported in sectors with high employment opportunities for the disadvantaged;
11. A model and procedures for training provision to people facing social exclusion developed

baseline.comment:
1. The SME sector is facing difficulties in terms of growth and new jobs generation. Since 2007, the Employment Generation Programme helped create over 6,700 new start-ups. 36% of the newly created start-ups are being run by women and 28.4% by young people Self-employment measure targeting people with disabilities has been implemented for the first time in the country by UNDP
2. Since 2007. over 8,300 people have acquired entrepreneurship skills by attending trainings organized by UNDP supported projects
3. Micro and small enterprises (MSEs) limited in their ability to grow and thus hire more workers. In 2014, 82 micro and small companies received help to expand their business, creating additional 119 jobs. Since 2007, 306 MSEs have been supported and 446 new long-term jobs have been created.
4. The activity rate among young people aged 15-24 is extremely low, i.e. 30.6%, which is almost one third of that of persons aged 25-49 (80.1% in Q42014). 4 Youth Info Clubs at four technical faculties have been opened in the country in 2014.
5. 1,530 active users of PRV.mk; 6,500 application downloads; over 1,5 million web site visitors
6. In the period from 2012 to 2014, 220 unemployed people got 6 months short-term employment. In average, 70% of them are women and app. 40% are youth (aged up to 29 years);
7. N/A
8. Lack of supporting activities in the area of marketing and promotion to help the growth of micro and small companies
9. National partners need to enhance their capacity for providing e-services to registered unemployed persons
10. National partners need to improve their capacities for more active cooperation with the private sector and its direct involvement in local level labour market analyses
11. The Adult Education Centre is still not fully operational; institutions' responsibilities are not yet clearly defined, there is lack of coordination between different institutions; There are no procedures for the implementation of educational activitie

target.comment:
1. Provide technical assistance and advice in the process of designing the National Employment Strategy and follow-up programmes that accelerate employment and quality jobs creation for all; 900 self-employments/small businesses established and 60 additional created - 30% young people aged up to 29 - 38% women - 20 Roma - 120 companies established by persons with disability (2016)
2. Strengthening entrepreneurship and management capacities of 1,500 unemployed people in business planning and financial management; Additional 150 people with disabilities will receive training on business management. Barriers and risks and mentoring services will be provided to those that will establish a business during the first year (2016)
3. Up to 200 additional jobs supported in the previously established companies
4. 5 Youth Info Clubs supported in university centers throughout the country
5. Number of young people who use the mobile application PRV.MK
6. Support the establishment of local partnerships for provision of social services to vulnerable groups that will create part-time employment for 300 hard to employ job-seekers.
7. Training of 50 people to provide professional services to the elderly through the Community Works Programme

actual.comment:
1. 942 people received coaching, training and small grants to start their own business. 35% of these new entrepreneurs are women and 29% are young people aged up to 29. Out of the 12 unemployed Roma who successfully completed the Self-Employment Programme, 9 started their new businesses.
2. 1,332 unemployed candidates underwent a training for strengthening their entrepreneurship and management skills and 1,256 obtained a certificate for successfully completing the training.
3. 72 micro and small companies received help to expand their businesses, creating another 111 jobs.
4. Contracts with 4 Youth Info Clubs were extended in 4 university centers. 1,732 students obtained information about job opportunities. The architectural design of the fifth Youth Info Club is developed and ready to be implemented in 2016 once a mutual agreement with the Faculty of Mechanical Engineering is reached.
5. PRV.mk is a smart application that brings the latest job openings directly to a mobile phone, including internships and volunteer positions. The app is functional for three mobile operating systems (Android, iOS and Windows Phone). Over 7,100 downloads and around 1,400 active users are registered by Play Store (Android). A new, advanced version of PRV.mk 2.0 has been introduced to all users, which will bring the latest news, tips and hints and other opportunities closer to young people.
6. The Community Works Programme supported 42 municipalities in tackling social exclusion on two fronts at once. Implemented by the Government, municipalities and UNDP, the Programme offered opportunities to 318 unemployed people to gain valuable skills while also providing social services to the most socially excluded groups in the country. Out of the 318 beneficiaries, 43% are young unemployed, aged up to 29. Over 10,000 socially excluded people in 42 municipalities have felt the benefits from the services provided through the Programme, with each municipality launching schemes of part-t

iati-activity.description: The programme will contribute to efficient implementation of the 2014 Operational Plan on ALMMs and its components

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1. Number of start-ups supported % of women employed % of youth aged up to 29 No. of Roma employed
2. Number of additional jobs created in successful small companies 3. Number of established Youth Info Clubs 4. Number of jobs created for unemployed men and women that belong to the hard to employ group. 5. Number of unemployed that went through the training programme; Number of new training programmes verified

baseline.comment: 1. The SME sector is facing difficulties in terms of growth and generation of new jobs generation. Since 2007, over 5,800 start-ups have been created through the program; 36% of the new start-ups are being run by women and 28.4% by young people A self-employment measure targeting people with disabilities has been implemented for the first time by UNDP 2. Micro and small companies (MSCs) are constrained in their ability to grow and hire more workers. 3. The activity rate of young people (15-24) is roughly half of the activity rate of adults (34.7% in 2013) 4. Unemployed vulnerable face difficulties and barriers when it comes to jobs seeking and employment. 5. There is a lack of programmes that can help match the needs of the local labour market with the qualified labour force

target.comment: 1. 900 small businesses established and 50 additional employments created in new small businesses i. 30% of job seekers are in the age category of 29 and below ii. 38% are women iii. 20 Roma 2. Up to 100 additional employments supported; 60% in micro businesses 3. Support provided for the creation of partnerships with academia and private sector to help bridge the gap between young graduates and the job market 4. Community service programme providing temporary employment for 100 job seekers from the vulnerable groups 5. Over 200 unemployed people trained in skills on demand on the labor market; 20 new standardized training programmes available

actual.comment: 1. Coaching, training, mentoring and small startup grants helped 940 unemployed people set up their own small businesses, creating 1,050 jobs; 36% of the newly created businesses are being run by women and 28.4% by young people 2. 82 micro and small companies received help to expand their businesses, creating another 119 jobs 3. 4 Youth Info Clubs have been established in university centers throughout the country; 1,300 students have obtained information about job opportunities; A mobile application PRV.MK has been developed to enable young people have access to realtime information on available jobs, internships and apprenticeship opportunities 4. Supported part-time engagement of 142 longterm unemployed (41% of them under 29) in 30 municipalities to deliver social services to vulnerable groups 5. 232 unemployed candidates completed vocational training courses in highdemand occupations. Initiated work on a system for adult primary education that will deliver equivalency diplomas and provide educational programmes adapted to adult needs

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Comprehensive citizens satisfaction survey designed and implemented. At least one consultative event organized to discuss the survey results. Crosscutting analyses prepared and decentralization strategic framework adjusted. A partnership programme designed and implemented. Local e-services study prepared. At least one consultative event organized to discuss the results. Local e-services road-map prepared. In-depth analysis of the existing Inter Municipal Cooperation practices and the current Inter Municipal Cooperation policies presented to the Government. Best Inter Municipal Cooperation practice award established and at least two Inter Municipal Cooperation arrangements supported. Assessment report on the possibility to establish a Unit for Support of Private Enterprises within the Centers for Regional Development, prepared. New Decentralization Programme for the period 2015 2020, prepared.

baseline.comment: No updated data and analyses of citizens perceptions on the quality of local services, resulting in policies and actions that do not reflect citizens priority needs. Lack of innovative partnership programme to address service delivery. No updated and sufficient data and analyses of existing local e-services and related needs and opportunities. Inter Municipal Cooperation evidence system established. Mid-term decentralization policy review completed. Lack of state financial support for Inter Municipal Cooperation, resulting in insufficient utilization of this tool for alternative service delivery. Centers for development of the planning regions face serious sustainability issues due to an inappropriate financing system. The existing decentralization programme expires in 2014, which creates a risk for the country to remain without a very important policy for the development of its local self-government system.

target.comment: Comprehensive information on citizens satisfaction with decentralization services made available to ensure that regional and local development policies are developed on an informed basis. An innovative Programme for Support of Partnerships between municipalities, civil society and business sector put into practice, ensuring involvement of all relevant local development stakeholders and actors. A study on existing e-services at local level and needs and possibilities for introduction of new e-services carried out, with recommendations for modernizing and increasing effectiveness and efficiency of local services. The mechanisms for support and promotion of Inter Municipal Cooperation improved and new Inter Municipal Cooperation practices operationalized to increase the economy of scale in the delivery of local services Assessment of opportunities for service delivery to private sector by the Centers for Development of Planning Regions completed and used for diversifying the portfolio of services and functions of the Centers. The Program for Sustainable Development of the Local Self-Government for the period 2015 - 2020 prepared in a participatory manner.

actual.comment: A comprehensive Citizens Perceptions Survey was carried out and presented to the Government, providing a wealth of information about the level of citizens satisfaction with the quality of local services. The first draft of the Study of Local e-Services Delivery was prepared in a participatory manner, including the following research: (1) E-services survey in 44 municipalities; (2) In-depth research regarding the delivery of local e-services in the municipalities of Tetovo, Veles, Cheshinovo - Obleshevo and Dojran; (3) In-depth analyses of web page contents in all municipalities (4) Report on the best international practice on local e-services delivery. The 2014 Report on the Status of the Inter-Municipal Cooperation was prepared. The findings and recommendations will be used for amending the Law on Inter-Municipal Cooperation and adjusting the Inter-Municipal Cooperation policy in order to meet the needs of the municipalities and the local communities. The findings and recommendations from all above described reports will be used for the preparation of the new Programme for Sustainable Local Development and Decentralization 2015 - 2020. The capacities of the Ministry of Local Self-Government for administering the e-register of Inter-Municipal Cooperation were strengthened, creating pre-conditions for an independent and efficient collection of information on the status of the Inter-Municipal Cooperation. With UNDP assistance, the by-law on prioritizing activities of wider relevance and interest that can be realized through inter-municipal cooperation for the period September 2014 - September 2017, was prepared and adopted by the Government, enabling more accurate targeting of the Governments incentives. The Inclusive Development Network of the Vardar planning region was awarded by the Ministry of Local Self-Government as the best Inter-Municipal Cooperation practice in the country for 2014 and was replicated in the North-East and Pelagonia planning regions, wit

target.comment: The Local e-Services Study finalized and endorsed by the Government to create a basis for the formulation of a new policy for modernization of municipal services The inclusive development networks of the Vardar Pelagonia and Northeast planning regions supported to implement priority actions derived from their Programmes and Action Plans. Technical support provided to the State Inter-Municipal Cooperation Commission for amending the Law on Inter-Municipal Cooperation and the related policy. The Centers for development of the five planning regions (Skopje, Polog, East, Southwest and Southeast Regions) supported in preparation of Programmes, Action Plans and Communication Strategies of the newly established Business Centers for Support of Small and Medium Enterprises . Implementation of activities for increasing regional competitiveness supported. Transfer of international best practices on distribution of state aid for private sector research and development at regional level and attraction of foreign investments enabled through study trip to the Czech Republic and three workshops with Czech experts in the country. Programme for Sustainable Local Development and Decentralization 2015 2020 finalized and endorsed by the Government and broadly disseminated. 2015 2017 Action Plan of the Programme for Sustainable Local Development and Decentralization 2015 2020 and Monitoring Methodology prepared and endorsed by the Government. Third Annual Conference on Sustainable Local Development and Decentralization, organized with the aim to gather all relevant stakeholders in taking stock of the implementation of the decentralization policy in 2015 and formulating joint recommendations and prioritizing actions for 2016. Potentials for development of forms of rural tourism in the four (4) least developed planning regions in the country (Northeast, Vardar, Southwest and Polog) mapped and rural tourism registers prepared, thus creating basis for more accurate preparation

actual.comment:
The final Draft of an Integrated Study on Local e-Services was discussed and endorsed by the Government Committee on e-Services. Integrated Regional Development Network (IRDN) was formed in the Pelagonia Planning Region, and the Platform for Regional Rural Action (PRRA) was established in the Northeast Planning Region. Both Networks prepared Programmes of Work and respective Action Plans and started with the implementation of priority activities. Premises where both Networks operate were refurbished. The Vardar Region Inclusive Network continued with implementation of the 2013 2015 Programme of work. Center for Development of Pelagonija Planning Region held 2 promotional events for increasing capacities of the business sector (one workshop on agricultural business and the other workshop on utilization of domestic and foreign financial instruments, organized with the Regional Chamber of Commerce). Centre for Development of Vardar Planning Region held the event for promotion of the three products: the Guide for investors, the Map/Collection of the Industrial Zones and the web portal. The economic operator presented the products before the mayors, as well as representatives of business and civil sector. Based on a pre-prepared analysis of existing practices and current Inter-Municipal Cooperation (IMC), a Draft Law amending the Law on IMC was prepared. The State Inter-Municipal Cooperation Commission was assisted in preparation of the 2015 IMC Status Report. The brochure Inter-Municipal Cooperation in the Republic of Macedonia was published.
Programs for Private Sector Support, including an Action Plan and Communication Plan for Program Implementation were prepared by the Business Centers established for support and advisory services to SMEs in Skopje, Polog, East, Southeast and Southwest Planning Regions. In all 5 Centers, altogether 28 informational events were organized and attended by a total of 1053 participants (586 men and 467 women), most of whom were repre
